segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Riding out from the gates of Dol-Makjar, into the darkness, Teor Pridesire, Thimble, Kattigan Vale, Tyranny, and Wicander Halovar, begin a journey whose end, at this point in time, we cannot see.
segments.summary: The party begins their journey from Dol-Makjar in pursuit of Casimir and Teor's brother

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Fittingly, it is difficult for any of you to see past even the snouts of your horses, or in Thimble's case, the dim light cast by the fluttering of your pixie wings; for rain falls from the sky overhead, (whooshing) close as you are to the Stormwrack here. Heading out into the darkness, the gates behind you, time is of the essence. Somewhere out there, a man who put a knife in the back of your beloved friend is walking free, chasing down the deed to a strong home, a fort at some far edge of civilization, a treasure that he was willing to sell your friend's life for. And just ahead of him, you hope, is Teor's brother, if they haven't gotten to him already.
segments.summary: The party travels in difficult rainy conditions, pursuing Casimir who killed their friend and is after Teor's brother

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Flying through the night, Thimble, what does it feel like to hold on to this purpose that you have set for yourself?
segments.summary: Brennan asks Thimble about her emotional state and purpose

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: It feels like everything else is disappearing. And with that singular goal in front of me, I'm able to leave the grief behind. I'm able to believe in this purpose, so wholly, it feels like like I'm going to make it right.
segments.summary: Thimble describes how her purpose helps her cope with grief

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Already, something deadly and burning within your heart is keeping you safe from something that, in its own right, might be even more terrifying.
segments.summary: Brennan describes Thimble's emotional state as protective but dangerous

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Teor, it's been a long time since you've seen your brother. As you ride out, does your mind drift to Casimir, the person who you're pursuing? Or to your brother, whom your prey, now themselves pursue?
segments.summary: Brennan asks Teor about his thoughts on Casimir and his brother

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: I think as I sit there in the rain, it begins to wash over me-- just how little I know about each of these men. My brother, I have not seen in years. The same is true for Casimir. And at one point, I would say that I knew them better than anyone. The the idea that I have of my brother has evolved, grown, and in some way committed himself to a cause so noble that even as I fear for his safety, I find jealousy almost swelling within me. The purpose that he found, the ability to shift fates that have affected all the people that I'm traveling with. How little I knew about him. And for Casimir, what could have gotten to a man that shared a banner with us? What could have pulled him in this direction? What don't we know? And as I sit in the light of Thimble's wings, I realize: I know next to nothing.
segments.summary: Teor reflects on how little he truly knows about both his brother and Casimir, feeling both fear and jealousy

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Rain mats the fur on either side of the bridge of your snout, leaning into the darkness, lost so much since the end of the war. And know so many people who seem to have faltered and fallen into losing even themselves.
segments.summary: Brennan describes Teor's physical state and references the war's aftermath

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Wicander, at the last possible moment, riding up the ridge, at this late hour, there's very few people on the road, but Dol-Makjar is large enough that there's still a handful of stragglers even in the wee hours of the morning. Some trundling a cart to get to some early farmers market by dawn's first light, others that have been trudging through weary miles. The last moment you look with the mountain peaks on either side, this is the last place in the road that you will be able to see the lights of the Villa Aurora in the city behind you. One more step of your horse and that home will disappear. Do you gaze behind you at this place or not?
segments.summary: Brennan asks Wicander if he looks back at Villa Aurora one last time

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam)
segments.content: Luckily, I'm sitting sidesaddle, so I can see-- I can see both ways right now. And yes, I do glance back one last time, but it's cold, I'm wet. I'm distracted. I'm feeling things I haven't felt in a long time, if not ever. I'm feeling depressed, I think, unclear of what my goal is. But, buoyed by Tyranny's yelling at me, I feel like answers lay ahead and that even though my family might have misled me, the truth of the universe will present itself to me. So, I shift my gaze forward with hope and say a quick prayer as we cross the threshold.
segments.summary: Wicander looks back at Villa Aurora but focuses forward, feeling depressed but hopeful for answers

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Regardless of what you've learned about the nature of your family's creed, there is always some comfort in ritual.
segments.summary: Brennan comments on the comfort found in ritual despite revelations

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Tyranny, the same is posed to you. You venture forth now having advised boldness and decisive action. having advised boldness and decisive action. And now the rain of this world, a world in which you were not born, falls upon your brow. Do you look back at the city you now leave? Or do your eyes stay fixed in the same direction as Wick's?
segments.summary: Brennan asks Tyranny if she looks back at the city

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: My eyes are on my tail that Wick is gripping so hard, and my ears are wet, and I do look back realizing that every opportunity I have had to leave the house of the Candescent Creed has been a really big party for me. I love to be out, and I love to meet people, and I love to see the goings on of the city around me. This time doesn't feel so good. And I'm realizing, as I sort of shake some rain off of my little floppy ears, that I'm maybe a little bit more domesticated than I once thought I was.
segments.summary: Tyranny reflects on how this departure feels different and worse than previous adventures

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Doing the right thing, that's supposed to come with immediate rewards, right? Otherwise, what makes it the right thing? Certainly, your material conditions having immediately deteriorated past the point of familiarity, that can't be what good deeds are rewarded with. If that were the case, then people would be behaving selfishly all the time.
segments.summary: Brennan reflects philosophically on the nature of doing the right thing and rewards

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Your ears slick to the side of your head, so soaked with rain, drooping down, matching the verticality of your horns like a giant middle finger pointing into the sky over your head.
segments.summary: Brennan describes Tyranny's rain-soaked appearance

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Kattigan, you're returning to Timmony.
segments.summary: Brennan notes Kattigan's destination

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: What's on your mind as you make your way back to where you have so long dwelled?
segments.summary: Brennan asks Kattigan about his thoughts returning home

segments.speaker: Kattigan Vale (Robbie)
segments.content: What's on my mind? Not a lot. Kattigan's in his body. He doesn't have much except for sensations. And he's watching his friend at the front of the pack leading everyone and he's hung back. He's chewing on a little bit of root in his mouth, and the rain is bringing him back to his senses from the drink in the city. And he's starting to come alive, and his heart rate's starting to race and he knows this feeling and it's a feeling of a hunt. And he's starting to feel good and excited. And excited is rare and strange for him. And as he rides a little bit harder off to the left, a little rush in the bush, and a quail sort of comes out of the bush and (whooshing) Wulferic just jumps out of the bush, snatches it, runs alongside him, (woofs) shakes it, and almost like a little smile, the way a dog can smile only after it's killed something, (whoosh) back off in the brush. And for a moment he's really excited because this is where he wants to be and he didn't know. And as he looks up front, everything feels dour, but he feels excited. And he notices between the two of them that both of their water skins are empty and he chuckles to himself, and he kicks his horse a little faster by then. And as he rides by, (popping) pops off the top of both their water skins so the rain can lead in while it's running. And then (clopping) just takes off.
segments.summary: Kattigan describes feeling alive and excited about the hunt, with Wulferic catching prey, and he helps collect rainwater

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam)
segments.content: I see that.
segments.summary: Wicander notices Kattigan's actions

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: I think we're in good hands.
segments.summary: Tyranny expresses confidence in their group

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Kattigan, this is the very beginning of our Soldiers' table, and this is where big decisions and big rolls happen.
segments.summary: Brennan announces the start of the Soldiers' table gameplay

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: I'm going to need a survival check. An individual can volunteer to make it, but I would ask if we do a group check, that everybody only roll if they have proficiency in survival.
segments.summary: Brennan calls for a survival check to track their quarry

segments.speaker: Multiple
segments.content: Group discussion about who should roll the survival check, with Kattigan having +4 and Thimble having +5 with proficiency.
segments.summary: Players discuss survival check mechanics

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: You guys can both roll. So we'll roll a group check, with a small group of only two, reminder that Wulferic is going to give you the help action here-- which he's able to do. And-- we're going to roll as a group, which means that we take the higher of the two.
segments.summary: Brennan explains the group check mechanics with Wulferic providing help

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: But I will tell you, you are riding in the rain at the gate of a massive city. Tracks intermingle, wagon wheels cut gouts into the road itself. Finding these tracks will be next to impossible in the night in the rain. The difficulty for finding all sets of tracks is going to be the highest difficulty that the game sets, which is a 30. Finding one of them is going to be a 25. And finding some clue that lets you at least rule out some bad options will be a difficulty of 20. So 30, 25, 20.
segments.summary: Brennan sets the difficulty classes for tracking: DC 30 for all tracks, DC 25 for one set, DC 20 for basic clues

segments.speaker: Multiple
segments.content: Discussion about using Guidance and rolling the survival check with advantage for Kattigan.
segments.summary: Players prepare to make the survival check rolls

segments.speaker: Kattigan Vale (Robbie)
segments.content: With the plus four, it's 19.
segments.summary: Kattigan rolls 19 total for survival check

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: 19? One away. Riding off into the rain, Kattigan, water, hooves prints, boot prints. Looking out. When the trail goes cold, a determined hunter has to move from what he can see to what he knows. You will have to think of what the choices Cyd would've made were. And then you'll have to think if those choices would've been knowable by those who pursue him with deadly intent. And we'll get into that in tonight's episode of Critical Role.
segments.summary: Brennan narrates the failed tracking attempt and transitions to the episode intro

segments.speaker: Multiple
segments.content: Players react to the near miss on the survival check and Robbie mentions forgetting about Guidance.
segments.summary: Players discuss the failed roll

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: What is SpectraVision? You mean the hotel pay-per-view system from the '80s?

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: Hell yes. I would always watch the first four minutes and 69 seconds.

segments.speaker: Bolaire Lathalia (Taliesin Jaffe)
segments.content: Nice.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: Those are some long minutes.

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: And then I would always watch those-- (wheezing) -- all the pornos and then I would pretend that it was, that it was this guy, Wallace, Wallace Shawn.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: Good old Wallace Shawn.

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: Woof, I would try to shut it off quick before they billed the room and my dad would blow a gasket. Now that was a hootenanny.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: And a half, I'm sure it was, but "Dispatch" is an equally exciting game. Decisions you make determine the outcome of the story. Are you with me? So no two playthroughs are the same.

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: Yeah. "Dispatch," blah, blah, blah, this better be good. Oh, where can I learn more about the game? Oh, oh, oh, I know how to answer this one. So wait, get out your phone. Yeah, turn on the flashlight. All right, and take a peek right up your butt hole (laughs). What a barf bag. (laughter) High five it.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: Thanks, Gale. Check out "Dispatch" now at bit.ly/CRdispatch and follow along @theadhocstudio. Matt, gag me with a spoon, back to you.

segments.speaker: Sir Julien Davinos (Matthew Mercer)
segments.content: Thank you very much, Liam and Gale.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: I love you, Gale.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: That shaved a year off my life.

segments.speaker: Sir Julien Davinos (Matthew Mercer)
segments.content: All of us. You can now bring your Daggerheart custom characters to custom miniatures. Big thanks to our friends at Hero Forge, you can now purchase special licensed Daggerheart collections focused on our fungril, simiah, and ribbet ancestries directly from the Hero Forge website. This collaboration helps our fans tell their stories within the magical world of Daggerheart, allowing them to better represent the characters they poured so much time, thought, and love into. From whole armor and outfit set to entire new species like tamarin, orangutan, and monkey simiah to multiple options for fungril mushroom caps, bringing these ancestries -- ancestries-- to Hero Forge. It would not have been possible without this wonderful new collaborator collection partnership. So please visit heroforge.com/collections to learn more today, and a big thank you to our friends at Hero Forge for partnering with us to make this happen. Laura Bailey, you're up.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: Hello, I have merch to tell you about. You remember, if you were OG, do you remember our original very first T-shirt that we did? Well, in celebration of our 10th anniversary and the start of Campaign 4, we did a Campaign 4 roll call T-shirt, you guys. Look, look, look, look, look, look, look. Look, look, look, look, look. It's our anniversary shirt! Thank you, Jordyn Torrence, for your fabulous design. The blue-- It's all the characters plus Mulligan, just like it was Mercer before. Then we've got our animal companions. So this is for the US and Canada. Then guess what, for the EU and for the UK, we have a gray one. Ooh. So anyway, there's that. We also have Critical Role 10-year anniversary posters, which I will now reveal to you and the cast. Wait. Vox Machina. Oh my god. Bells Hells. I mean, Mighty Nein. Shut up, I know. And Bells Hells. Okay, so the artist Tom Jilesen, you're amazing. Each of these posters is 13 by 18, printed on a good solid card stock. Here we go, it's called McCoy silk, look it up. Then if you collect all three, you guys, they go together and look it, look it. Oh wait, no, it's backwards. Jeez, it's backwards. The threads of fate lineup. Collect all three, frame them side by side for an epic tableau. You're welcome.

segments.speaker: Sir Julien Davinos (Matthew Mercer)
segments.content: Those are immediately getting framed at my house. This holiday season is upon us and our holiday vinyl album "Critical Role Presents Winter's Crest" is here to ring in the holiday with you and your loved ones. If you haven't checked it out yet, featuring 11 festive tracks, this album is a journey of jubilee through all three Critical Role campaigns with our own takes on holiday classics, as well as all new tracks to ring in the holidays. This deluxe edition also comes signed by all of us with exclusive extras inside. It sounds better than this, trust me. You can find it on the US Critical Role-- Find it on US Critical Role Shop or ScanlanShorthaltMusic.com and listen this to as warm up for a fourth annual Critmas Can't Miss Sale starting next Monday. Our biggest sale of the entire year, Laura, will run in all shops from November 10th through December 14th. There you'll find dice, accessories, games, and apparel up to 60% off in time for the holidays. Get all the Critmas deets at critrole.com/critmas2025. Ashley and Liam.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: Oh man, yeah, we got some news. If you're looking for some reading material this holiday season our friends at Dark Horse Comics have you covered with their Humble Bundle of Critical Role comics. Collection includes all four volumes of the prequel series, Vox Machina Origins, and the comic adaptation of the Mighty Nein.

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: And the best part, in my humble opinion, is that every purchase supports the Critical Role Foundation. When you buy a Humble Bundle bundle, you can choose how your money is divided between Dark Horse, CRF, and Humble Bundle. So grab some deals on books while also doing a little good. Sorry, I'm bad at reading.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: And this bundle is available. It's available until Saturday, November 15th at 11:00am Pacific, so be sure to grab yours at humblebundle.com/critrole. Humble bumba.

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: Humble Bundle.

segments.speaker: Sir Julien Davinos (Matthew Mercer)
segments.content: Awesome. I think with that, back to you.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: We return to the city of Dol-Makjar, where events have been compounding pretty, I'd say, fast and furious for these last several hours. It has been, I believe, just about two days since the execution of Thjazi Fang, a noted war hero and beloved friend and family member and hated foe of many of those gathered here at this table. Executed under the authority not of the Revolutionary Council of Dol-Makjar and its proud heritage of being the birthplace of the war against the gods. No, Thjazi Fang was executed by the authority of the Chamber of Lords-Advisory, those members of the Sundered Houses, including the House Halovar, of which one Wicander Halovar has just fled after arriving at Hal's doorstep. And a young Occtis Tachonis, eighth of the proud line of Tachonis, one of the many Sundered Houses whose reach seems to extend across the landscape.
segments.summary: Brennan recaps the events of the campaign, focusing on the execution of Thjazi Fang and the political situation in Dol-Makjar

segments.speaker: Thaisha Lloy (Aabria Iyengar)
segments.content: I like it. I like it they suck so much.

segments.speaker: Murray Mag'Nesson (Marisha Ray)
segments.content: So proper.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: I'm having a good time. We're telling it, it's a magical story. It's literally what it is.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Our last episode began with a surprising moment where Occtis, aware that his family was searching for him, perhaps for reasons unbeknownst to him, perhaps because he had sort of betrayed them in a sense revealed conspiracy to save Thjazi Fang, was brought under the protection of one Julien Davinos. Under orders from his father, General Raimond Davinos, right hand to the great Sundered House of Royce! The Lady Aranessa Royce being herself the ex-wife of the late Thjazi Fang. Julien taking Occtis there was also in the company of one Vaelus of the Mournvale, an elven warrior in search of an artifact stolen by this Thjazi Fang. Boy, this guy seems to have gotten around.
segments.summary: Brennan continues the recap, explaining how Occtis was protected by Julien Davinos and the connection to various factions

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: This guy's a real jerk!

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: This guy's a real jerk!

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Seems to have gotten his hands on the Stone of Nightsong, an ancient artifact and relic of the deceased goddess of life, your goddess. You, yourself, some eight centuries old, having seen her in the flesh, one of the only people here that's ever seen a god, or I should say one of two people at this table who's seen a god.
segments.summary: Brennan reveals information about the Stone of Nightsong and Vaelus's ancient history with seeing gods

segments.speaker: Bolaire Lathalia (Taliesin Jaffe)
segments.content: Thank you.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: For indeed, in our last episode, we discovered that Bolaire is not a man but a mask crafted.
segments.summary: Brennan reveals that Bolaire is actually a magical mask, not a person

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley Johnson)
segments.content: Ya mean?

segments.speaker: Bolaire Lathalia (Taliesin Jaffe)
segments.content: Thank you.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam O'Brien)
segments.content: Are we still talking about the game?

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Indeed, in the bowels of The Archanade, Bolaire, his business aired out. His dirty laundry left out to dry in a letter left to one Murray Mag'Nesson of the Penteveral. But what could've seen you two sort of come to each other as foes instead found the burgeoning of a friendship. As indeed, Azune Nayar of the Brethren Hall, Murray Mag'Nesson with the Penteveral, Bolaire of the Archanade, and now Halandil Fang of the newly named Hallowed Round, all find themselves tied to a city that descends into darkness and despair. Revealing secrets, forged fast friendship. And I'll tell you what forged that friendship even faster was when the four of you went searching, knowing that the lights had gone out at the Davinos Palazzo, where you knew Occtis to be, that Thaisha had gone in pursuit.
segments.summary: Brennan recaps the alliance formed between various faction representatives and their search for Occtis

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Arriving there, you found melted wax, Azune speaking a word in an ancient language, "Remember." The candle reconstituted, and Hal heard the footsteps of a spectral fox, none other than Pincushion, Occtis' fox familiar! You pursued it all the way to the Lloy Estate, the home of Thaisha's family since departed for the capital city of Dol-Rungja. There with Occtis' body, Sir Julien, the Lady Aranessa, the Groundskeeper Rohor, and Vaelus, all beholding our young, gem-toothed, rapscallion wizard and the man who is in fact a mask crafted by halflings to perform a play so potent in its performative capability that it could lay low a god, worked an act of magic as the stars aligned. And on a portent roll of a nat20, the Stone of Nightsong was removed. And for the first time ever, to your knowledge by mortal hands, was a death reversed. Almost.
segments.summary: Brennan recaps the magical resurrection attempt at the Lloy Estate

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: And it is in that almost that we return to Occtis Tachonis. Visions. General Raimond Davinos dead. Necromantic force unleashed. Shades, the summoning of those spirits of unlife, bent only on the destruction of living things, to once again grasp that which is corroded by their very touch. Occtis. Aranessa is speaking. Thaisha is bleeding from a wound on her chest. A glass rapier in Bolaire's hand. Partially behind Lady Aranessa is Julien. Aranessa is speaking. Whatever has occurred here is something unknown to the enemies of the House of Royce, unknown to the enemies of all those who still believe in a free world, or as Thjazi would have said, "That can still hear the falcon's cry." You hear the voice, but it's blurry to you. You feel the weight of your own flesh. Your living body, when it rested, sought comfort and ease, but now, you feel not that you have lost your sense of touch, but that it has actually gone internal. You feel as tendons move in your body, you feel bones twist against muscle, ligament, and sinew, the awareness of your body as a thing, which is all it is now, someone's speaking to you. You realize you cannot become unaware of your breath, lest it stop. Now, for you, breathing is either conscious or absent. Blood isn't flowing. Any part of you that you cannot command is so still that on some level, it frightens you, like some part of you knows it is rotting. In this moment, a number of medic
segments.summary: Brennan describes Occtis's disturbing resurrection experience and current state

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: al facts become obvious to you. You no longer require food or water. You do not feel tiredness in the same sense as you once did, but you also no longer feel energy, drive, passion of that sort. Your body does not become restless, nor can it ever be restful. You are aware that you will not age. And it is very likely that the functions of your body to drink wine with a friend, to perhaps, one day, carry on the Tachonis line, if that was ever something that you dreamed of, family, old age, to lie on a deathbed and look up at those around you that gave reverence or admiration to the life you led, every indication is that that has passed from the realm of possibility. And yet, people are still talking to you.
segments.summary: Brennan describes the existential reality of Occtis's undead state - no longer needing food, water, or sleep, but also lacking energy and passion, unable to age or experience normal life milestones.

segments.speaker: Thaisha Lloy (Aabria Iyengar)
segments.content: Can you hear me? Are you okay?

segments.speaker: Occtis Tachonis (Alexander Ward)
segments.content: I think. I'm here! This is strange. Sorry. A-a-are you okay? Are you good?

segments.speaker: Thaisha Lloy (Aabria Iyengar)
segments.content: No, you died. So I'm still going through that. Also, back off of your sword I was slowly impaling myself on to interpose myself between the two of you.

segments.speaker: Occtis Tachonis (Alexander Ward)
segments.content: Right. Sorry, I-- Why are you? Why? Seeing the sword slide out of you again.

segments.speaker: Occtis Tachonis (Alexander Ward)
segments.content: I um... I died?

segments.speaker: Murray Mag'Nesson (Marisha)
segments.content: Oh, you like were dead-dead. Your guts was all over the place. I mean, look at how much blood is over here.

segments.speaker: Murray Mag'Nesson (Marisha)
segments.content: There's a body trail.

segments.speaker: Thaisha Lloy (Aabria Iyengar)
segments.content: Okay, okay, Murray.

segments.speaker: Murray Mag'Nesson (Marisha)
segments.content: All right, sorry.

segments.speaker: Halandil Fang (Liam)
segments.content: What did we miss?

segments.speaker: Occtis Tachonis (Alexander Ward)
segments.content: It's a little jumbled, but my-- I'm so sorry I-I-- Julien, I am-- M-m-my family showed up. They killed everyone.

segments.speaker: Azune Nayar (Luis Carazo)
segments.content: As you're starting to admit that, I'm approaching Julien. If your hand is still outstretched with the sword in your hand, I'm very gently lowering it, and I whisper to you: Give him a chance. You may not know it yet, but you are among friends.

segments.speaker: Sir Julien Davinos (Matt)
segments.content: I draw the blade back, and just turn around and walk about 10 feet away, and just fold my arms.

segments.speaker: Bolaire Lathalia (Taliesin)
segments.content: Glass sword vanishes. Turn to the-- Yes.

segments.speaker: Occtis Tachonis (Alexander Ward)
segments.content: I haven't seen my family in years. I haven't seen them since I came to the Penteveral. I don't know what they're doing. I don't know why. I have no idea why they were here, what they wanted. I don't know why they took-- They took my heart.

segments.speaker: Vaelus (Ashley)
segments.content: Do you know why they would've placed that stone inside of you?

segments.speaker: Occtis Tachonis (Alexander Ward)
segments.content: No, I don't. Who is holding the stone? Or is it still floating?

segments.speaker: Murray Mag'Nesson (Marisha)
segments.content: I think I had Mage Handed, it kind of floating, if I recall. So I think it's kind of, it's in my little basket weave of magical energy.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Following the tracks from here, you've got Wulferic (rapid sniffing) sniffing out in the rain in the early morning light. I will allow, there's a couple different roads that they could've taken here. And I will say that there's effectively two that you're able to rule out right away. The main road that diverges out from the Dvalmar Pass. So the Dvalmar Pass is the big pass that runs east from Dol-Makjar; that road you know doesn't lead to Gormalay. It doesn't lead to Timmony, the realm, the Kingdom of Timmony. You would be looking for probably two different roads or highways that go north. One of them is the Pilgrims' Road, which is this ancient dwarven road that goes over the mountaintops to some ancient holy sites. That place has been largely abandoned since the Goddess of the Forge was defeated. There's not a lot of pilgrims running around anymore. Then there's the King's Highway. That's the main road that leads to Timmon's Rock, which is the capital city of Timmony. That is the fastest road to where you're going. It's a big old highway. It stretches off of the Dvalmar Pass. It would peel off probably two miles outside of town, that road would split.
segments.summary: Tracking reveals two possible routes north: the abandoned Pilgrims' Road and the King's Highway to Timmon's Rock

You know about it because you've been traveling a lot, right? But Cyd's been a city slicker for like 12 years, right? So you're able to rule out the Pilgrims' Road as an option. Basically you're left with the King's Highway, or there is a forest, the Dahapshanee Wood, which is a big alpine, almost like a conifer pine rainforest. It's cool and misty and rainy there almost all the time. There are a lot of vines and other plants there. It's like a cold weather, high altitude rainforest.
segments.summary: Deduction narrows options to King's Highway or Dahapshanee Wood forest

If you travel in that direction, you'll be traveling on a big open road, which will be fast, but also, I think on a 20, you know that's the road that anyone who's pursuing you guys would probably take that road as well. It doesn't mean that they'll be as fast as you or travel as lightly as you. And then there is the forest, which normally would slow people down, it would not slow you down. If Casimir went that way, if Casimir basically made a choice that was: Oh my god, they're definitely right behind me. I have to go somewhere that the carriages can't follow me.

Or, do you take the King's Highway? The dangers that-- Both paths have danger to them. The dangers of the King's Highway will be anyone pursuing you will be able to keep apace with you, but also you'll definitely have more opportunities to have other ways of tracking. People will've seen people, there will be towns, there will be inns and taverns and things like that.

segments.speaker: Kattigan (Robbie)
segments.content: That's a lot of stuff.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: Yeah. Oh yeah. You don't think he was like letting people know that we were here?

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam Riegel)
segments.content: No, no, this is a nice--

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: Just nice, he's just a nice guy.

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam Riegel)
segments.content: He's just a nice man.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Fire out. He seems like he understands keeping a low profile.

segments.speaker: Kattigan (Robbie)
segments.content: Whatever he's doing, he's been safe out here for a long time.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: That's true.

segments.speaker: Kattigan (Robbie)
segments.content: I don't love it.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: If anybody's keeping an eye on him, if he does it every night, it might be weird if he doesn't.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: You're so good. God, we're so lucky. It's so crazy.

segments.speaker: Kattigan (Robbie)
segments.content: What did he talk about? Discussing this.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: He's going to give me a sword.

segments.speaker: Kattigan (Robbie)
segments.content: Well, that's neat.

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: He has his daughters' toys still and he uses telescope to spy on the King's Road and also to study clouds.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: Yes, I'm going to--

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: he locks up as it's getting dark. And you see, he goes over one last time and reflexively, you can see he's agitated. He goes over, adjusts the banner again and looks to the little hanging light, he goes and fixes it, so the candle's a little more straight, in the little hanging beacon lantern. Looks at it, looks at the valley, looks at it.
segments.summary: The gnome innkeeper anxiously tends to his banner and light as evening approaches

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: I don't mean to pry, I do not read... Gnomish?

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "Oh, well. Not at all. No, it's hardly the language of the world. Yes, it's gnomish writing."

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: It seems well-tended to. Could I pry and ask what it says?

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "Well, it says 'Welcome home.'"

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: "Welcome home." For your daughters?

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "Yes, for all three of them. For you see," he looks out and goes,

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: (chuckles) How dare you.

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: This is trauma, Brennan. This is just years of trauma coming to the surface.

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam)
segments.content: You're fine. Yeah.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: You look at him and see, you see he says, "Cerebel, Demuriel, and Elanadel."
segments.summary: The innkeeper names his three daughters

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: What was the second one?

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Demuriel.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Demuriel.

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam)
segments.content: Demuriel.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: The last one?

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Arabel?

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: Arabel.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Arabel's last.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Cerebel.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Cerebel.

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam)
segments.content: Oh, that was the first, Cerebel.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Oh no, it was last.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Cerebel, Demuriel, and Elanadel.

segments.speaker: Thimble (Laura Bailey)
segments.content: Elanadel.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: Ray?

segments.speaker: Kattigan Vale (Robbie)
segments.content: Yep.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Elana Del Ray.

segments.speaker: Wicander Halovar (Sam)
segments.content: Yep. (chuckles) She's not going back. (laughter)

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: He looks, yeah, he looks at you and says, "Yes, the writing says welcome home and the exclamation mark you can find to either side of the door." You see he points at the fireworks in the crates.
segments.summary: The innkeeper explains the banner message and points to fireworks as exclamation marks

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: How long has it been since you last saw your three daughters?

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: (tongue clicks) "(exhales) Well, it's been about 15 years, two months, 17 days."
segments.summary: The innkeeper reveals exactly how long his daughters have been gone

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: You love them very much. I can tell. Thank you for sharing your home with us. It is a rare thing to put faith in someone who values the efforts of those that have lost near and dear to themselves as well.
segments.summary: Teor acknowledges the innkeeper's love for his daughters and thanks him for hospitality

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "Well."

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: My brother is who we are searching for. My kin.
segments.summary: Teor reveals they are searching for his brother

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "There is no distance too great for family. I've often thought, if I would travel from this place in search of them with my terrible back and awful knees, but then the thought of not being here if they were to return and need me. If Jasavi were here, it would be very different. I sort of-- I had prepared in my mind how I would weather knowing that something awful had happened. Do you know what I mean? That if I knew that they were not coming home. If I knew that they were not coming home. But every day, the hope diminishes, but does not vanish. And therefore, we have to keep the banner tended to because the thought that maybe tossed aside by storms or left somewhere else, that one of them might come home and not find it welcome. I cannot bear."
segments.summary: The innkeeper explains his internal struggle between searching for his daughters and staying in case they return home

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: I reach into a pouch on my hip and pull out my banner in the hand. I know exactly what you mean.
segments.summary: Teor shows his own banner, sharing in the innkeeper's understanding

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: He walks up and reaches up at his full height to pat your mighty forearm. And he goes, "My daughters would've loved you. They heard the cry."
segments.summary: The innkeeper comforts Teor and mentions his daughters heard the falcon's cry

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: The falcon's cry stretches far and wide.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "Oh yes. It's why I kept those terrible tin soldiers in a drawer. I don't know why I let them play with them. But then again, isn't that what you want? Brave young girls, go out and face the problems of the world, head on?"
segments.summary: The innkeeper reflects on his daughters' toys and their bravery

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: Yes. Yes, it is. You inspired those closest to you to go out and make change. I will tell you that as we go through this place, if any of our ears catch word of the names you have taught us this night, we will be sure that they know that their father is waiting for them and that the visit is long overdue.
segments.summary: Teor promises to tell the daughters their father is waiting if they encounter them

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "(sniffs) Oh, that's very kind. I'll be ready. I'll be ready." And you see that he pats you again and looks out and goes, "We'll get you all rested up and packed on your way. I appreciate you asking and for not thinking me crazy for having kept it up for these long years."
segments.summary: The innkeeper thanks Teor for his kindness and understanding

segments.speaker: Teor Pridesire (Travis Willingham)
segments.content: Who would think such a thing? The outward appearances? No, uh-uh.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: "You go a little mad in the mountains, but it's a mad world so." And you see that he walks inside and at the end of that watch, I think Kattigan, you awake, looking at this doll as the sun rises and you are still waiting. Give me one last perception check, if you'd be so kind.
segments.summary: The innkeeper goes inside and Kattigan awakens for perception check

segments.speaker: Kattigan Vale (Robbie)
segments.content: Hmm. 18.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: As the dawn creeps in, the last moments of night down in the forest on that 18, I feel like you can hear something far away like a whisper on the wind or a moan. Suspicion creeps up your spine, that this may be the last warm place before you head into true danger. There are things down there in the forest looking for light and warmth.
segments.summary: Kattigan hears ominous sounds from the forest and senses approaching danger

segments.speaker: Kattigan Vale (Robbie)
segments.content: I took my watch on the highest point of the house and instead of patrolling like Teor would on the grounds, I was glassing like you were hunting, just sort of looking everywhere. Distracted by this doll and I'd been turning over in my hands and it's you know, tattered old wood. And as I've been holding it and watching, I sort of-- It's beautifully carved in the front and I turn it over and sort of slide the back of the cloth down at the end of the watch as the sun comes up and you can just see rot and termite ridden, portions of it and the entire hollow back of this doll has been eaten out from years of being set aside and forgotten. And he looks at it one last time and just hucks it off the edge of that drop behind the chicken coop and heads back inside to wake everyone up at the end of watch.
segments.summary: Kattigan examines the doll during watch, discovers it's rotted and hollow, then throws it away

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: The next day has risen as you go to wake everybody up.
segments.summary: The new day begins as Kattigan wakes the group

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: I am up.

segments.speaker: DM (Brennan)
segments.content: Mm-hmm.

segments.speaker: Tyranny (Whitney Moore)
segments.content: I am up and I am crouched on Wick's chest. (laughter)
segments.summary: Tyranny is perched on Wick's chest while he sleeps
